posts.title: The Death of Socrates
posts.notes: Best post. Save for when we have an audience.

tweets.text:
A painter with no commission walked into the 1787 Paris Salon and ended another man’s career with a single canvas.

Peyron (left) was hired to paint The Death of Socrates. David (right) painted his own version anyway. Uninvited. Same scene. Same year.

Look at what David does. Socrates reaches for the poison cup mid-sentence. Everyone around him is falling apart. One man can’t even look.

Socrates isn’t dying yet. He’s still teaching. David paints him like someone who’s already won the argument.

David’s painting destroyed Peyron’s reputation overnight. Critics barely mentioned the commissioned version.

Two years later, the Revolution. David sat in the National Convention and voted to execute King Louis XVI.

Peyron died broke in 1814. Nobody remembers his painting.

Jacques-Louis David, The Death of Socrates, 1787. The Met.

posts.title: Damascus Room
posts.medium: Wood, paint, gold leaf, stone, glass, plaster
posts.dimensions: 22 ft 2 in. × 16 ft 8½ in. × 11 ft 5 in.

tweets.text:
Someone dismantled an entire room in Damascus, packed it in crates, and shipped it to Manhattan.

Built in 1707 for a wealthy Syrian family. Carved wood panels, painted flowers, gold leaf, Quranic inscriptions running the full perimeter. 22 feet long, 16 feet wide, 11 feet tall.

The dealer who bought it in 1934 took the walls apart piece by piece. They sat in storage for decades before the Met reassembled them. Not a replica. The actual room, 5,700 miles from the house it belongs to.

Damascus Room, 1707. The Met.

The most reproduced image in history was made by a 70-year-old who said everything he drew before 50 was worthless.

Hokusai published this around 1831. He'd been drawing waves for over thirty years. None were right until this one.

It's one print in a series called Thirty-Six Views of Mount Fuji. Fuji appears in every image. In The Great Wave, it's the small triangle in the background, dwarfed by the water.

This is another from the same series: fishing boats at Choshi. Same ocean, same mountain, completely different mood.

The original woodblock was carved in cherry wood and pressed thousands of times. Each pull wore the block down slightly. Colors faded. Lines softened.

Only a few hundred impressions survive. The Met has one. The Art Institute of Chicago has another. No two are identical.

Katsushika Hokusai, The Great Wave off Kanagawa, ca. 1831. The Met.

The most famous American painting was made in Germany by a German.

Emanuel Leutze painted this in Düsseldorf in 1851, using the Rhine as a stand-in for the Delaware. Almost everything is wrong. The flag didn't exist yet. The crossing happened at midnight in a snowstorm, not dawn. The boats are the wrong type. Washington was 44, not the old man shown here.

Leutze didn't care. He painted it during the 1848 European revolutions. He wanted to show Germans what a successful revolution looked like.

He made two versions. The first stayed in Germany. A British bombing raid destroyed it in 1942. This one, the second, hangs at the Met. 21 feet wide.

Emanuel Leutze, Washington Crossing the Delaware, 1851. The Met.

posts.title: The Unicorn Rests in a Garden

tweets.text:
Nobody knows who made The Unicorn Tapestries. 520 years old. Woven from wool, silk, silver, and gold thread. No record of the artist, the patron, or why they were commissioned.

Rockefeller bought them in 1922 for about $1 million. They hang in The Cloisters, a medieval monastery the Met built on the northern tip of Manhattan.

Before that, they spent decades in a barn in the French countryside. Twelve-foot tapestries woven with gold thread, draped over potato bins to keep them from freezing.

The Unicorn Rests in a Garden, ca. 1495-1505. The Met Cloisters.

Aztec gold lip plug, 1400s. A labret is a piercing worn below the lower lip. This one is shaped like a serpent about to strike.

The tongue is articulated. It actually moves. When the wearer talked or moved their jaw, the snake's tongue flicked back and forth.

Only the emperor and highest nobles could wear one. In Aztec society, labrets marked who had the right to speak and be heard. 2½ inches long. Solid gold. 600 years old.

It wasn't alone. This eagle-head labret sat in the same gallery. Same gold. Same period. Same function. The open beak has teeth carved inside it.

The Spanish melted most Aztec goldwork after the conquest. Fewer than a dozen gold labrets survive worldwide.

Mexica (Aztec), Serpent Labret with Articulated Tongue, 1300-1521. The Met.

In 1886, a family tomb was found near the Valley of the Kings in Egypt, completely intact. 3,000 years and nobody had touched it.

This is a mummy board, a carved wooden cover placed directly over the wrapped body inside the coffin. It shows Iineferty, wife of Sennedjem, a foreman who painted the pharaohs' tombs.

Not royalty. A craftsman's wife. Carved around 1250 BC. The braided wig, the pleated gown, the lotus on her forehead. She outlasted every dynasty that followed.

Egyptian, Mummy Board of Iineferty, ca. 1279-1213 B.C. The Met.

posts.title: Armet (Helmet)
posts.notes: Weak story. Needs a better angle to justify posting.

tweets.text:
Italian armet, ca. 1440. The first helmet that fully enclosed a knight's head while being light enough to fight in.

Two cheek-pieces hinge open like doors. You put your head in, snap them shut, lock the visor down. 7 pounds. Breathing through slots barely wider than a coin.

Gunpowder made it obsolete within a century.

Italian, Armet, ca. 1440. The Met.

posts.title: Field Armor of King Henry VIII

tweets.text:
Henry VIII ordered this armor for his last military campaign. He was 53, so crippled by gout he needed a crane to lift him onto his horse.

50 pounds of Italian steel, custom-built in 1544 to fit a body that could barely walk.

Field Armor of King Henry VIII, ca. 1544. The Met.

The Egyptians who buried this hippo were afraid of it.

It's 8 inches long, made of clay, and 4,000 years old. They painted it with lotus flowers and marsh plants from the Nile. Then they snapped off three of its legs before sealing the tomb.

Hippos killed more people along the Nile than any other animal. Egyptians believed tomb figurines could come alive in the afterlife. A hippo that couldn't walk couldn't charge.

His name is William. A British officer named him in a 1931 magazine story. The Met's unofficial mascot ever since.

Egyptian, Hippopotamus ("William"), ca. 1961-1878 B.C. The Met.

Caravaggio was 26. This was his audition — painted for Cardinal Del Monte, the man who would become his first major patron.

Four musicians mid-rehearsal. The one with the lute looks directly at you. Scholars think that's Caravaggio's own face.

The figure on the far left was originally Cupid — wings, quiver of arrows. X-rays found them under the paint. Caravaggio turned a god into a boy reaching for grapes and never told anyone.

He painted himself into his audition tape and buried a god under it.

Caravaggio, The Musicians, 1597. The Met.

posts.title: Rolltop Desk
posts.medium: Oak, cherry, mahogany, 10+ woods; mother-of-pearl; gilt bronze
posts.notes: Secret compartments need video/GIF to land. Save for video format.

tweets.text:
This desk has more secret compartments than most spy movies.

Turn the key: side drawers spring open. Press a hidden button under each one and they swing aside, revealing more drawers behind them.

David Roentgen, 1776. Marie Antoinette and Catherine the Great both ordered his furniture.

Pull out the writing surface and the rolltop automatically retracts. Behind the bronze plaque? A reading stand with built-in inkwell that unfolds at the turn of a key.

A dozen different woods. Mother-of-pearl inlay. Every surface does something.

David Roentgen, Rolltop Desk, ca. 1776-79. The Met.

The king is the smallest figure. That’s the point.

Olowe of Ise carved this 5-foot post from a single log for the palace of the Ogoga of Ikere, a Yoruba king in southwestern Nigeria, around 1910. The king sits at center, crowned. His senior wife towers behind him. She’s the one who placed the crown on his head.

Five figures, one log, zero seams.

Olowe of Ise, Veranda Post (Opo Ogoga), ca. 1910-14. The Met.

In 1897, British soldiers broke into the royal palace of the Kingdom of Benin, a powerful state in what is now southern Nigeria, and looted thousands of objects from its shrines. This brass head was one of them.

A newly crowned king would commission one to honor the previous ruler. A carved ivory tusk fit into the top. This one dates to the 1700s or early 1800s.

It passed through a German collector, a New York dealer, and Christie's before the Art Institute of Chicago bought it in 2003. Six owners in 106 years, after sitting on one altar for at least a century.

Edo peoples, Head (Uhunmwun Elao), 18th century. Art Institute of Chicago.

Before the katana, there was the ken.

Straight. Double-edged. Based on Chinese swords that crossed the sea centuries earlier. This one is from the 5th century, 700 years before samurai culture produced the curved blades everyone pictures.

It was buried in a kofun, an ancient Japanese tomb mound. In 1906, the Imperial Museum in Tokyo traded it directly to the Met. Whatever they got in return, they wanted it more.

Here's what replaced it. A katana from around the same period the ken disappeared. Curved, single-edged, built for a draw-and-cut motion from horseback.

The straight blade (top) is 1,500 years old and weighs 12.6 ounces. The curved blade took over by the 10th century and defined Japanese swordmaking for the next thousand years.

Japanese, Ken Blade, 5th century. The Met.

You'd walk right past this. It looks like a candlestick.

It's a microscope. The decorative cap unscrews to reveal the lens. Three more are hidden inside the tube.

Claude-Siméon Passemant built it around 1750 for Louis XV. He was the king's personal instrument maker. He lived inside the Louvre. About 10 of his microscopes survive.

At Versailles, even your lab equipment had to match the furniture.

Claude-Siméon Passemant, Compound Microscope, ca. 1750. The Met.

A nautilus shell from the Indian Ocean. A silver-gilt sea monster from Delft, a Dutch city famous for its craftsmen. A goddess perched on top.

Dutch merchants brought these shells back from the spice routes in the early 1600s. Silversmiths turned them into drinking vessels no one would ever drink from.

Made in 1607. Only five others from this period survive. The Rothschild family owned this one for generations. Christie's sold it in 2023. Cleveland bought it that same year.

The nautilus that grew this shell died over 400 years ago. The shell is worth more now than ever.

Cornelis Jansz van der Burch, Nautilus Cup, 1607. Cleveland Museum of Art.

This sword has no point. It was never meant to stab anyone.

Executioner’s sword, 1634. The flat, blunt tip is the giveaway. Designed for one motion only. Two-handed grip, downward swing.

No point meant no thrusting. Short cross-guards because you didn’t need hand protection. Many had inscriptions. Prayers, mostly. “When I raise this sword, I wish this poor sinner receives eternal life.”

Last sword execution in Europe: Switzerland, 1868.

German, Executioner's Sword, 1634. Cleveland Museum of Art.

posts.title: Battle of the Nudes

tweets.text:
Ten naked men trying to kill each other. No one knows why.

Antonio del Pollaiuolo engraved this scene in the 1470s or 80s. The figures look like the same body copied and rotated into different fighting poses. Swords, daggers, axes, a bow. A chain links the two men in the center.

Art historians have spent centuries trying to identify the story. A myth? A battle? An allegory about the soul trapped in the body? Pollaiuolo signed it in Latin, which means he expected educated buyers. But he left no title, no caption, no explanation.

The engraving is huge for its time. Over 16 by 24 inches. One of the largest prints made in 15th-century Italy. Pollaiuolo was a goldsmith, painter, sculptor, and bronze caster. He cut this plate himself.

Multiple impressions survive in museums around the world. But the one in Cleveland is the only known first-state print. Before any reworking of the plate. Before any corrections. The very first pull.

What the ten men are fighting about, nobody knows.

Antonio del Pollaiuolo, Battle of the Nudes, 1470s–80s. Cleveland Museum of Art.

posts.text:
Ten naked men trying to kill each other. No one knows why.

Antonio del Pollaiuolo engraved this scene in the 1470s or 80s. The figures look like the same body copied and rotated into different fighting poses. Swords, daggers, axes, a bow. A chain links the two men in the center.

Art historians have spent centuries trying to identify the story. A myth? A battle? An allegory about the soul trapped in the body? Pollaiuolo signed it in Latin, which means he expected educated buyers. But he left no title, no caption, no explanation.

posts.title: Adeline Ravoux

tweets.text:
She hated it. Adeline Ravoux was 13 when Van Gogh painted her portrait at her father's inn in Auvers, north of Paris. She thought it looked nothing like her.

He finished the portrait on June 24, 1890. He shot himself on July 27. Thirty-three days.

Adeline lived to 76. A photograph from the 1950s survives. Same face. Same steady gaze. Same set of the mouth. She was wrong about the painting.

Vincent van Gogh, Adeline Ravoux, 1890. Cleveland Museum of Art.

posts.text:
She hated it. Adeline Ravoux was 13 when Van Gogh painted her portrait at her father's inn in Auvers, north of Paris. She thought it looked nothing like her.

He finished the portrait on June 24, 1890. He shot himself on July 27. Thirty-three days.

Adeline lived to 76. A photograph from the 1950s survives. Same face. Same steady gaze. Same set of the mouth. She was wrong about the painting.

Vincent van Gogh, Adeline Ravoux, 1890. Cleveland Museum of Art.

posts.title: The Troubadour

tweets.text:
Daumier went blind painting this.

He spent most of his career drawing politicians as pigs, bloated kings, and crooked judges for French newspapers. Over 4,000 lithographs. People called him the "Michelangelo of caricature."

The figure is a troubadour, a wandering medieval poet-musician. The subject was everywhere in 19th-century French art, usually rendered with lace and delicate sentiment. Daumier painted his like a boxer. Thick, simplified forms. Dark palette. No romance.

Oil on fabric. Likely painted between 1868 and 1873, the last years he could still see. He died six years later in a cottage a friend gave him because he couldn't afford rent.

Honoré Daumier, The Troubadour, 1868–73. Cleveland Museum of Art.

posts.text:
Daumier spent most of his career drawing politicians as pigs, bloated kings, and crooked judges. Over 4,000 lithographs for French newspapers. People called him the "Michelangelo of caricature." He went blind before he finished this painting.

The figure is a troubadour, a wandering medieval poet-musician. The subject was everywhere in 19th-century French art, usually rendered with lace and delicate sentiment. Daumier painted his like a boxer. Thick, simplified forms. Dark palette. No romance.

The canvas is small. About 33 by 22 inches. Oil on fabric. Likely painted between 1868 and 1873, the last years he could still see. By 1873, his eyesight was gone. He died six years later in a cottage given to him by a friend because he couldn't afford rent.

Honoré Daumier, The Troubadour, 1868–73. Cleveland Museum of Art.

posts.title: Portrait of a Woman

tweets.text:
Rembrandt probably didn't paint all of this.

By his late 20s he had more portrait commissions than he could finish. He ran a workshop in Amsterdam. Assistants painted the clothing, the backgrounds, the hands. Rembrandt did the face, signed it, took the money.

This woman's lace collar and gold jewelry say she paid well. The face has the brushwork. The rest? Could be anyone in the studio.

She had a companion. A man's portrait, probably her husband, hung beside hers. At some point both paintings were cut down from their original shape. Nobody recorded when or why.

His ended up at a museum in Sakura, Japan. Hers in Cleveland. 6,500 miles apart.

Rembrandt van Rijn, Portrait of a Woman, 1635 or earlier. Cleveland Museum of Art.

posts.text:
Rembrandt was 25 when he moved to Amsterdam. Within a few years, he had so many portrait commissions he couldn't finish them alone. He hired assistants to help paint his clients.

This woman was probably one of those jobs. Oil on wood, about 30 inches tall. Her lace collar and gold jewelry signal money. Rembrandt likely painted her face himself. The rest? Maybe not.
